choices.A: Importing firewall address objects from managed devices
choices.C: Importing static and dynamic route configurations from managed devices
choices.B: Importing interface mappings from managed devices

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A & B - correct.

I go with A and B, but why is C not correct? You are either doing a device import or policy import and not both at the same time. If you pick C then you can only pick 1 as the device import does not import fw object . But if you assume the question is referring to Policy import than A and B are correct.

Question says automated, interface mapping can ask for mapping adjustment upon import, hence not automated. Object import and routing config part are imported with no adjustments upon import, therefore, AC

choices.D: Protocol options allows administrators to configure which Layer 4 port numbers map to upper-layer protocols, such as HTTP, SMTP, FTP, and so on.
choices.A: Protocol options allows administrators a streamlined method to instruct FortiGate to block all sessions corresponding to disabled protocols.
choices.B: Protocol options allows administrators the ability to configure the Any setting for all enabled protocols which provides the most efficient use of system resources.
choices.C: Protocol options allow administrators to configure a maximum number of sessions for each configured protocol.

questions.question_text:
An administrator has created a VPN community within VPN Manager on FortiManager. They also added gateways to the VPN community and are now trying to create firewall policies to permit traffic over the tunnel; however, the VPN interfaces are not listed as available options.
What step must the administrator take to resolve this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Based on documentation, page 454 of the Study Guide, we need to install the configuration before doing the policies.

Answer: A
1- Create a VPN Community
2- Install VPN Configuration
3- Add IPsec Firewall Policies
4- Install the Policies

comments.content: I agree, the correct answer is A.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
study guide page 454

Selected Answer: A
The virtual interfaces are not created until the VPN Configuration is installed

Selected Answer: A
A for sure

Selected Answer: A
Based on StudyGuide - A

choices.A: Install the VPN community and gateway configuration to the FortiGate devices, in order for the interfaces to be displayed within Policy & Objects on FortiManager
choices.D: Create interface mappings for the IPsec VPN interfaces, before they can be used in a policy.
choices.C: Refresh the device status from the Device Manager so that FortiGate will populate the IPsec interfaces.
choices.B: Set up all of the phase 1 settings in the VPN community that they neglected to set up initially. The interfaces will be automatically generated after the administrator configures all of the required settings.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
With snat-route-change disable, sessions using SNAT keep using the same outbound interface, as long as the old route is still active.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct - Study Guide, page 146

Selected Answer: D
Same here, D.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct. 

SNAT 
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Using-SNAT-route-change-to-update-existing-NAT/ta-p/198439
config system global
 set snat-route-change enable
end
The option 'snat-route-change' can control what action the existing SNAT session needs to take after route change. 
By default, it is disabled. So after a routing change, sessions with SNAT keep using the same outbound interface, as long as the old route is still active.
When 'snat-route-change' is enabled, after a routing change, routing information is flushed from existing SNAT sessions;.
D is the correct.

Took the test a few weeks ago, there is a variant on this question where the snat-route-change setting is enabled. So the answer would be B in that case.

With snat-route-change enable will it perform the same action as non-natted traffic , aka it will flag the session as dirty and restablish. 
With snat-route-change disable it will stay on the current interface unless the interface has gone down.
D is correct

choices.A: The session would remain in the session table, but its traffic would now egress from both port1 and port2.
choices.B: The session would remain in the session table, and its traffic would egress from port2.
choices.C: The session would be deleted, and the client would need to start a new session.
choices.D: The session would remain in the session table, and its traffic would egress from port1.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
A is wrong, because TZ is for TimeZone of the server, and it's used to calculate the base value of the weight.
B is good, because as the weight is lower, more chance the server will be chosen and more packets will be sent.
C is wrong, because the server used to validate it's contract was the one with the I flag.
D is wrong, because the firsts servers received from DNS resolution are those with D glag.

Selected Answer: B
B cuz everything else is wrong!

Selected Answer: B
B other answers are incorrect

B, without any doubt.
Study guide page 174-176

C is wrong as there is no "D" flag on ip 64.26.151.37
Cannot be D because "F" flags means server is down !

Selected Answer: B
B - is correct

ACD eliminated
correct answer : B
Definitely not D

choices.B: There is a natural correlation between the value in the Packets field and the value in the Weight field.
choices.C: FortiGate used 64.26.151.37 as the initial server to validate its contract.
choices.D: The first server provided to FortiGate when it performed a DNS query looking for a list of rating servers, was 121.111.236.179.
choices.A: Servers with a negative TZ value are less preferred for rating requests.
